subject: White House says that US President Trump wants US forces to return home from Syria as soon as possible
UK PM May is to make a Brexit appeal in which she will urge the Commonwealth to bolster trade and forge new relationships
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Japan Tobacco (2914 JT) March cigarette sales volume fell 14.5% Y/Y to 7.2bln
content:
AUSTRALIA

AMP Capital (AMP AT)
- Perpetual CEO Lloyd and BT Financial CEO Cooper are said to be the leading candidates for AMP’s next CEO. (Newswires)

BHP Billiton (BHP AT)
- A 22mln share block traded on Friday which was said to be due to prime broker refinancing. (Newswires)

Lynas (LYC AT)
- Co. Q3 NDPR output 1.3k tonnes vs. Prev. 1.2k tonnes Q/Q, sales revenue AUD 85.9mln vs. Prev. AUD 69.3mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Perpetual (PPT AT)
- Co. March-end FUM saw net outflows of AUD 1.3bln at AUD 30.2bln. (Newswires)

Perseus Mining (PRU AT)
- Co. reports Q3 gold output rose 13% Q/Q to 64.0k ounces. (Newswires)

Praemium (PPS AT)
- Co. March-end FUA rose 5.2% Q/Q to AUD 7.8bln. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT)
- Co. is set to declare a force majeure on some Rusal-linked contracts following the US sanctions. (Newswires)

Seven West Media (SWM AT)
- Merger discussions between Co. and Fairfax (FXJ AT) are said to remain ongoing, although Seven West Media would like to see an increase in share price. (Newswires)

Woolworths (WOW AT)
- Couche-Tard, PetroChina and KKR are all interest in buying 230 petrol stations from Woolworths (WOW AT). (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Japan Tobacco (2914 JT)
- Co. March cigarette sales volume fell 14.5% Y/Y to 7.2bln. (Newswires)

Kansai Paint (4613 JT)
- Co. lowers FY17/18 oper. profit forecast to JPY 36bln from JPY 39bln. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT)
- Co. is in late discussions for investment in data storage firm Cohesity at a USD 1bln valuation. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT)
- Co. is examining mass output of optical communications devices for small satellites by using optical disc technology. (Nikkei)

Toho (9602 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 oper. profit fell 5.3% Y/Y to JPY 47.6bln. (Newswires)

Yamada Denki (9831 JT)
- Co. lowers FY17/18 oper. profit forecast to JPY 38bln from JPY 75bln. (Newswires)

Other News
- Japan PM Abe is reportedly planning to propose a new frame work for trade talks, in an aid to hope for Trump to join the TPP. (Newswires)
- S&P affirmed Japan at A+; outlook revised to positive from stable. (Newswires)
- Japan and EU said to be set to sign a trade deal by mid-July. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

KT Corp (030200 KS)
- South Korean police are expected to summon Co. CEO as part of investigation on funding. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Co. is said to plan launching MicroLED TVs this year. (Nikkei)

subject: UK Q1 Visa spending fell by the most since Q4 2012 as it dropped 1.4% vs. Prev. decline of 1.3%, while March Visa spending fell by most since October last year at -2.1% vs. Prev. -1.0%
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights Include New Zealand Performance of Services PMI and Indian WPI

US equity futures gap higher at the reopen as fears of a greater escalation of geopolitical tensions subside despite the airstrikes in Syria over the weekend, as the US and allies hit only 3 targets instead of the previously considered 8 targets
Russian President Putin said that further strikes by the West on Syria would bring chaos to global affairs
Note: We will be broadcasting the Asia-Pac service over the the Asia and FX channels this evening; to ensure coverage for our Ventrilo users
UK PM May reportedly agrees to give parliament a full debate on the Syria airstrikes and has called for emergency debate this Monday afternoon regarding Syria
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Mar) 1120.0B vs. Exp. 1200.0B (Prev. 839.3B). (Newswires)
Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Mar) 1330.0B vs. Exp. 1800.0B (Prev. 1173.6B)
Chinese Money Supply M2 (Mar) Y/Y 8.2% vs. Exp. 8.9% (Prev. 8.8%)

China may ask Japan to team against Trump’s steel tariffs, according to reports on Friday. (Kyodo)

Japan PM Abe is reportedly planning to propose a new frame work for trade talks, in an aid to hope for Trump to join the TPP. (Newswires)
 

UK/EU

Moody’s raised Spain’s sovereign rating by one notch to Baa1; outlook stable. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Luxembourg at ‘AAA’; outlook stable. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Poland at BBB+; outlook revised to positive from stable. (Newswires)


FX

US Treasury Department report showed that India was added to the watchlist of currency manipulators, although no country was actually named as a manipulator. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (13 Apr) 1008 (Prev. 1003). (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US, UK and France conducted airstrikes in which over 100 missiles were launched at 3 Syrian targets in response to the chemical weapons use. US President Trump stated US is prepared to sustain response until Syria stops use of chemical weapons but added that US does not seek an indefinite presence in Syria, while Chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Dunford said that this wave of airstrikes was finished. (Newswires)

US Ambassador to the UN Haley said that there will be further sanctions on Russia which will be announced this Monday. (Newswires)


US

US Commerce Secretary Ross said he is optimistic on reaching a deal in principle on NAFTA, possibly in the third week of May. However, he also added that if no accord is reached by the Mexican election, a deal is unlikely to be reached until the end of the year. (Newswires)

US President Trump said to have deep concerns on the direction Special Counsel Mueller is taking. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Equity futures on Friday initially took out the prior day’s highs rising to 2680 just before the cash open, when the gains were reversed and the EMINI faded back down. Further pressured by softer University of Michigan and JOLTS data was seen, with the EMINI returning to the 2650 area, a level that was revisited plenty of times this week. Despite earnings for three major financial names today (JPM, Citi, Wells – all beating the top and bottom line), the sector closed red on Friday, with the financial sector underperforming. Energy was the outperformer, supporting the SPX for the session on the back of higher oil prices. Apart from the financial earnings, the main story stock specific stories today surrounded chip names, Qualcomm (QCOM) & Broadcom (AVGO), with the latter announcing a $12bln share repurchase programme after market on Thursday, and the former reportedly looking to become private in the next few months according to sources. M&A news was relatively light compared to recent sessions, where the focus was on Mylan (MYL) reportedly in advanced negotiations for German Merck’s KGaA (MRK GY) consumer health unit, sources suggest the bidding value is around $3.5bln. SPX -0.29% at 2656, NDX -0.42% at 6628, DJI -0.50% at 24360.

Treasury yields were little changed on Friday with most action in the short end of the curve where 2yr yields rose to fresh (almost) decade highs. The rise in 2yr yields resulted in further flattening of the 2s10s and 2s30s curves (by around 3pbs). Treasuries were generally fulfilling their haven role, inversely moving to the direction of equities – particularly so after weak US data. Elsewhere, ahead of next week’s auction of 5yr TIPS, the US Treasury has asked primary dealers opinion on increasing 5yr TIPS issuance in the second half of the year. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle half-a-tick higher at 120-15+.
